bestBHT.bht: The city of Ephesus was known for its devotion to the goddess Diana, with thirteen other cities having a vested interest in the temple there. This reverence can be compared to the veneration of images and pictures in the Roman Catholic Church. Despite the tumultuous nature of the assembly, Luke's account of these events is seen as historically accurate. Gaius and Aristarchus, who were directly involved in these happenings, would have been witnesses to the vivid scene. By dismissing the assembly, Paul ensured the safety of himself and his companions, averting the imminent danger they faced.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: what man . . . knoweth not that the city of the Ephesians is a worshipper of the great goddess Diana
Thirteen cities of Asia had an interest in the temple, but Ephesus was honored with the charge of it.
With this we may compare various legends concerning images and pictures in the Romish Church, such as the traditional likenesses of Christ, which were said to be 'not made with hands'
Albert Barnes: Dismissed the assembly...applied to the irregular and tumultuous 'assemblage'".
The "assemblage" which had convened in a riotous manner.
Archibald T. Robertson: This vivid, graphic picture given by Luke has all the earmarks of historical accuracy."
Certainly both Gaius and Aristarchus were lively witnesses of these events since their own lives were involved.
John Gill: He ordered them to break up, and every one to return home in peace, and go about his own business.
Thus Paul, and his companions, were delivered from an imminent danger they were exposed to.

The Ephesians' worship of the goddess Diana was well-known, with other cities also having a stake in the temple.
